(1987–1991) | type = [[Subsidiary]] | industry = [[List of entertainment industry topics|Entertainment]] | founded = {{Start date and age|1987|12|18}} as '''Columbia Pictures Entertainment, Inc.'''
{{Start date and age|1991|08|07}} as '''Sony Pictures Entertainment Inc.''' | founder = [[Sony]] | hq_location_city = [[Sony Pictures Studios|10202 West Washington Boulevard]], [[Culver City, California|Culver City]], [[California]] | hq_location_country = United States | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = {{unbulleted list|[[Tony Vinciquerra]] ([[Chairman]] and [[Chief executive officer|CEO]])|Stacy Green (Executive Vice President & Chief People Officer){{Cite web|url=https://www.sonypictures.com/corp/management.html|title = Senior Management Team | Sony Pictures Entertainment}}|Jon Hookstratten (Executive Vice President, Administration & Operations)}}Ravi Ahuja (Chairman, Global Television Studios and Corporate Development){{Cite web|url=https://www.sonypictures.com/corp/seniormanagementteam/raviahuja.html|title = Ravi Ahuja | Sony Pictures Entertainment}} | products = {{Plainlist| * [[Film|Motion pictures]] * [[Television programs]] * [[Online games]] * [[Mobile Entertainment]] }} | services = {{Flatlist| * [[Filmmaking|Film production]] and [[Film distribution|distribution]] * [[Television Production]] * [[Broadcast syndication|Television Syndication]] * [[Online game]]s * [[Video on demand]] * [[Digital distribution]] * [[License|Licensing]] }} | revenue = {{down}} US$7.097 billion | revenue_year = FY2020 | operating_income = {{up}} US$753 million | income_year = FY2020 | owner = [[Sony Corporation of America]]
{{small|([[Sony Group Corporation]])}} | parent = [[Sony Entertainment]] | divisions = {{Plainlist| * [[Sony Pictures Motion Picture Group|Motion Picture Group]] * [[Sony Pictures Television|Television Group]] * [[Sony Pictures Home Entertainment|Home Entertainment]] }} | num_employees = 9,500 | num_employees_year = 2019 [https://www.sony.net/SonyInfo/csr_report/employees/info/] | website = {{url|https://www.sonypictures.com/|sonypictures.com}} | footnotes = [https://www.bloomberg.com/profile/company/CPEI:US Sony Pictures Entertainment Inc.: Private Company Information]{{cite web |url=https://www.sony.net/SonyInfo/IR/library/presen/er/17q4_supplement.pdf|title=Supplemental Information for the Consolidated Financial Results for the Fourth Quarter Ended March 31, 2018 |publisher=Sony Corporation|location=Tokyo, Japan|page=10|date=2018-04-27|access-date=2018-05-06}} }} '''Sony Pictures Entertainment Inc.''' (commonly known as '''Sony Pictures''' or '''SPE''', and formerly known as '''Columbia Pictures Entertainment, Inc.''') is an American diversified multinational mass media and entertainment studio [[Conglomerate (company)|conglomerate]] that produces, acquires, and distributes filmed entertainment (theatrical motion pictures, television programs, and recorded videos) through multiple platforms. Through an intermediate holding company called Sony Film Holding Inc., it is operated as a subsidiary of [[Sony Entertainment|Sony Entertainment Inc.]], which is itself a subsidiary of the multinational technology and media conglomerate [[Sony|Sony Group Corporation]].{{cite web|publisher=Sony Pictures Entertainment|url=https://www.sonypictures.com/corp/aboutsonypictures.html|title=About Sony Pictures|access-date=January 28, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190321065216/http://www.sonypictures.com/corp/aboutsonypictures.html|archive-date=2019-03-21}}Sony Pictures Entertainment Inc. is a wholly owned fifth-tier subsidiary of Sony Corporation. It is directly owned by Sony Film Holding Inc., a subsidiary of Sony Entertainment Inc., a subsidiary of Sony Group Corporation. ([https://www.sony.co.jp/SonyInfo/IR/library/h27_q4.pdf FY2015 Securities Report] (in Japanese), Sony Corporation) Based at the [[Sony Pictures Studios]] lot in [[Culver City, California]] as one of the [[Major film studios|"Big Five" major American film studios]], it encompasses Sony's [[film|motion picture]], [[television production]] and [[Broadcast syndication|distribution]] units. Its sales in the fiscal year 2020 (April 2020 – March 2021) was reported to be $7.16 billion.{{cite web| url=https://variety.com/2021/biz/asia/games-music-film-sony-doubled-profits-1234962021/| title=Sony's Doubled Profits Driven By Games, Music and Film| author=Patrick Frater| date=27 Apr 2021| access-date=26 Jul 2021| website=[[variety.com]]}} All of SPE's divisions are members of the [[Motion Picture Association]] (MPA).{{cite web|url=https://www.motionpictures.org/who-we-are/#our-history |title=Who We Are|publisher=MPA}} Sony's film franchises include ''[[The Karate Kid (franchise)|The Karate Kid]]'', ''[[Ghostbusters (franchise)|Ghostbusters]]'', ''[[Spider-Man in film|Spider-Man]]'', ''[[Jumanji (franchise)|Jumanji]]'', ''[[Men in Black (film series)|Men in Black]]'', and [[Sony's Spider-Man Universe]]. == History == On September 1, 1987, [[The Coca-Cola Company]] announced plans to spin off its assets of [[Columbia Pictures]], which it had owned since 1982. Under this arrangement, Coca-Cola would sell its entertainment assets (a.k.a. Coca-Cola's Entertainment Business Sector) to [[TriStar Pictures]], of which it owned 39.6%. Tri-Star would be renamed as Columbia Pictures Entertainment, Inc. (CPE), with Coca-Cola owning 49%, its shareholders owning 31%, and Tri-Star's shareholders owning 20%.Dick, Bernard F. (1992) "Columbia Pictures: Portrait of a Studio" (p. 46). [[The University Press of Kentucky]]. {{ISBN|0-8131-1769-0}}.{{Cite web|url=https://appext20.dos.ny.gov/corp_public/CORPSEARCH.ENTITY_INFORMATION?p_nameid=1289584&p_corpid=1177827&p_entity_name=Columbia%20Pictures&p_name_type=%25&p_search_type=BEGINS&p_srch_results_page=0|title = New York Department of State Division of Corporations - Entity Search: Columbia Pictures Entertainment, Inc.|access-date = August 5, 2013}} As part of a merger plan, the two television business, comprising Columbia/Embassy Television and [[TriStar Television|Tri-Star Television]], merged altogether to form a new incarnation of the original [[Columbia Pictures Television]].{{Cite news |date=1987-10-21 |title=Coke's EBS & Tri-Star Merge TV Biz, Forming Col Pictures TV |pages=512, 528 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]}} The merger enabled three top Tri-Star executives, namely Arnold Messner, who ran [[TriStar Pictures|Tri-Star Telecommunications]], Victor A. Kaufman, who ran the main Tri-Star Pictures studio, and [[Scott Merrill Siegler|Scott Siegler]], who ran [[TriStar Television|Tri-Star Television]] to stay on, while four of the Coca-Cola Entertainment Business Sector had departed, namely [[Barbara Corday]], who ran [[Columbia Pictures Television|Columbia/Embassy Television]] as president, Herman Rush and Peter Seale, who ran [[Coca-Cola Telecommunications]] and Brian McGrath, who was the president of the Coca-Cola Entertainment Business Sector.{{Cite news |date=1987-10-28 |title=Coke Reorganizing TV Division After Merging It With Tri-Star; Two Execs Seek Syndie Rights |pages=43, 72 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]}} In early December 1987, former Coke EBS vice president Kenneth Lemberger had exited the post to join [[TriStar Pictures|Tri-Star Pictures]], displacing Roger Faxon, who had joined Columbia Pictures as senior vice president of the studio.{{Cite news |date=1987-12-09 |title=Lemberger Exits Coke For Tri-Star |pages=3, 6 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]}} The merger was approved by shareholders on December 15, 1987, and it was completed two days later, and that the Columbia and Tri-Star brands would be used as separate and autonomous production entities, and are part of CPE whole, along with the prior assets, units and commitments of the former Coca-Cola Entertainment Business Sector, which included all feature, TV, home video, pay cable operations, the Entertainment Sector's feature production deal with [[Nelson Entertainment]] and its ties with an investment in [[Castle Rock Entertainment]], and [[20th Television|TeleVentures]], a company continues to own, which was linked to three independent companies [[TriStar Television|Tri-Star Television]], [[Stephen J. Cannell|Stephen J. Cannell Productions]] and [[Witt/Thomas Productions]], and Merv Griffin Enterprises continue to function as a separate operation.{{Cite news |last=Tusher |first=Will |date=1987-12-23 |title=It's Official: Colpix Entertainment Formed Of Tri-Star; Coke Entities |pages=4, 22 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]}} A new company was formed in early 1988 with the Tri-Star name to take over the studio's operations.{{Cite web|url=https://appext20.dos.ny.gov/corp_public/CORPSEARCH.ENTITY_INFORMATION?p_nameid=1367154&p_corpid=1252551&p_entity_name=Tri-Star%20Pictures&p_name_type=%25&p_search_type=BEGINS&p_srch_results_page=0|title = State of New York Division of Corporations - Entity Search: Tri-Star Pictures, Inc.|access-date = August 5, 2013}} In early January 1988, CPE announced that they would revive the Triumph branding for the new worldwide subsidiary, [[Triumph Films|Triumph Releasing Corporation]], which was functioned as a theatrical distributor, marketing and promotion for [[Columbia Pictures|Columbia]] and [[TriStar Pictures|Tri-Star]] films, and named Patrick N. Williamson as president of the unit and the company provided administrative services related to distribution of its films in North America, while internationally, would be responsible for the direction of each studio.{{Cite news |date=1988-01-06 |title=Columbia Resurrects 'Triumph' |page=7 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]}} On September 28, 1989, [[Sony]] obtained an option to purchase all of [[The Coca-Cola Company]]'s stock (approximately 54 million shares or 49% of the outstanding shares) in CPE for $27 per share. The next day, Sony also announced that it reached an agreement with Guber-Peters Entertainment Company, Inc. (NASDAQ: GPEC; formerly [[Barris Industries]], Inc.) to acquire CPE for $200 million when Sony hired [[Peter Guber]] and [[Jon Peters]] to be its co-chairmen. This was all led by [[Norio Ohga]], who was the president and CEO of Sony during that time.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/28/business/sony-has-high-hopes-for-columbia-pictures.html|title=Sony Has High Hopes For Columbia Pictures|author=David E. Sanger|date=1989-09-28|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=2017-07-26|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} The hiring of Guber and Peters by Sony to run Columbia was conflicted by a previous contract the producers had signed at [[Warner Bros.]] [[Time Warner]]'s chairman, [[Steve Ross (businessman)|Steve Ross]], threatened Sony with a lawsuit for [[breach of contract]]. The lawsuit would be subsequently dropped when Sony sold half-interest in [[Columbia House]] and cable distribution rights to Columbia's feature films, TV movies, and miniseries to Warner Bros. That same agreement also saw Columbia sell its 35% interest in the Burbank Studios and acquired [[Lorimar|Lorimar Studios]], previously the [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer|MGM]] lot, from Warner Bros.''Warner, Sony settle suit over producers'' (November 17, 1989). Los Angeles: [[Associated Press]].Medavoy, Mike and Young, Josh (2002). ''You're Only as Good as Your Next One: 100 Great Films, 100 Good Films, and 100 for Which I Should Be Shot'' (p. 210). [[New York City]]: [[Atria Books]] On October 31, 1989, Sony completed a friendly [[takeover]] bid for the rest of shares (51%) of CPE, which was a public company listed on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE: KPE), and acquired 99.3% of the common stock of the company. On November 8, 1989, Sony completed the acquisition by a "short-form" merger of its wholly owned subsidiary Sony Columbia Acquisition Corporation into CPE under the [[Delaware General Corporation Law]]. Sony also completed a tender offer for shares of common stock of the Guber-Peters Entertainment Company on November 6, 1989, and acquired the company 3 days later. The acquisition cost Sony $4.9 billion ($3.55 billion for shares and $1.4 billion of long-term debt) and was backed (financed) by five major Japanese banks [[Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation|Mitsui]], [[MUFG Bank|Tokyo]], [[Fuji Bank|Fuji]], [[MUFG Bank|Mitsubishi]] and [[Industrial Bank of Japan]].Rudolph B (1994) ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20071017002414/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,981894,00.html So many dreams so many losses.]'' ''Time'' vol. 144, no. 22 (November 28, 1994)Griffin N, Masters K (1996) ''Hit and Run: How [[Jon Peters]] and [[Peter Guber]] Took Sony for a Ride in Hollywood.'' ([[Simon & Schuster]], {{ISBN|0-684-83266-6}})Nathan, J. (1999) ''Sony: The Private Life.'' (Houghton Mifflin, {{ISBN|0-395-89327-5}}, {{ISBN|0-618-12694-5}}) The company was renamed as Sony Pictures Entertainment on August 7, 1991.[https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1991-08-08-fi-464-story.html She Holds Torch for Sony Pictures Entertainment], latimes.com Also that year, Jon Peters left Columbia to start Peters Entertainment with a three-year exclusive production agreement at the studio at first, before transitioning to a non-exclusive deal at the studio.{{Cite web|last=Frook|first=John Evan|date=1994-02-22|title=Sony, Peters change nature of their deal|url=https://variety.com/1994/film/news/sony-peters-change-nature-of-their-deal-118478/|access-date=2021-10-24|website=Variety|language=en-US}} Longtime CPE employee [[Laurie MacDonald]] also left to start Aerial Pictures at the studio, first for a two-year deal, before going to [[20th Century Fox]] in 1993, and being swallowed up by [[Amblin Entertainment]] later that year, eventually setting up [[DreamWorks Pictures|DreamWorks]].{{Cite web|last1=O'Steen|first1=Kathleen|last2=Brodie|first2=John|date=1993-11-10|title=Aerial duo to Amblin|url=https://variety.com/1993/film/news/aerial-duo-to-amblin-115711/|access-date=2021-10-24|website=Variety|language=en-US}} Sony has since created numerous other film production and distribution units, such as creating [[Sony Pictures Classics]] for art-house fare, by forming Columbia TriStar Pictures (also known as the Columbia TriStar Motion Picture Group) by merging Columbia Pictures and TriStar Pictures in 1998, revitalizing Columbia's former television division Screen Gems. It expanded its operations on April 8, 2005, when a Sony-led consortium acquired the legendary Hollywood studio [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] (MGM), in a US$4.8 billion [[leveraged buyout]], through the holding company [[MGM Holdings]] Inc.''[https://money.cnn.com/2004/09/13/news/fortune500/twx_mgm/?cnn=yes Sony nabs MGM for $5B, source says]'', ''CNN'', September 14, 2004. This in effect re-united the MGM studio name, with the MGM main studio lot, although somewhat confusingly, the bulk of the pre-May 1986 original MGM library ended up at Time Warner via the [[Ted Turner]]-[[Kirk Kerkorian]] "[[Turner Entertainment|Turner Entertainment Co.]]" transactions. The post-April 1986 MGM library consists of acquisitions of various third-party libraries, such as the Orion Pictures catalogue, leading to MGM's [[RoboCop (2014 film)|2014 remake of ''RoboCop'']]. In July 2000, a marketing executive working for Sony Corporation created a fictitious film critic, [[David Manning (fictitious writer)|David Manning]], who gave consistently good reviews for releases from Sony subsidiary [[Columbia Pictures]] that generally received poor reviews amongst real critics.{{Cite news |date=2 March 2004 |title=Legal fight over fake film critic |work=BBC News |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/film/3524759.stm}} Sony later pulled the ads, suspended Manning's creator and his supervisor and paid fines to the state of Connecticut{{Cite news |last=Emanuella Grinberg |date=9 March 2004 |title=Moviegoers to settle with studio after being lured by phony critic |work=CNN|url=http://www.cnn.com/2004/LAW/03/09/phony.critic/index.html}} and to fans who saw the reviewed films in the US.{{Cite news |date=3 August 2005 |title=Sony pays $1.5m over fake critic |work=BBC News |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/4741259.stm}} On June 4, 2008, SPE's wholly owned group 2JS Productions B.V. acquired Dutch production company [[2waytraffic]] N.V., famous for ''[[Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?]]'', acquired from the original production company Celador, and ''[[You Are What You Eat]]'' for £114.3 million ($223.2 million in US dollars). In 2011, the Sony Pictures computer network was breached and approximately one million user accounts associated with the SonyPictures.com website were leaked.{{Cite web|url=https://mashable.com/2011/06/02/sony-pictures-hacked/|title = Sony Pictures Website Hacked, 1 Million Accounts Exposed|date = June 2, 2011|publisher = mashable.com}} On November 18, 2012, Sony Pictures announced it has passed $4 billion with the success of releases: ''[[Skyfall]]'', ''[[The Amazing Spider-Man (2012 film)|The Amazing Spider-Man]]'', ''[[21 Jump Street (film)|21 Jump Street]]'', ''[[Men in Black 3]]'', ''[[Hotel Transylvania (film)|Hotel Transylvania]]'', ''[[Underworld: Awakening]]'', ''[[The Vow (2012 film)|The Vow]]'', and ''[[Resident Evil: Retribution]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.deadline.com/2012/11/skyfalls-669-2m-global-helps-20th-century-fox-post-best-ever-4b-worldwide/|title='Skyfall's $669.2M Global Helps 20th Century Fox's Post Best Ever $4B Worldwide|first=Nikki|last=Finke|date=November 18, 2012}} On November 21, 2013, SPE and Sony Entertainment's CEO [[Michael Lynton]] announced that SPE will shift emphasis from movies to television by cutting its 2014 film slate.{{cite news|author=David Lieberman|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|url=https://www.deadline.com/2013/11/sony-pictures-vows-to-cut-costs-250m-through-2016/|title=Sony Pictures Vows To Cut Costs $250M+ Through 2016|access-date=November 22, 2013|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131123062645/http://www.deadline.com/2013/11/sony-pictures-vows-to-cut-costs-250m-through-2016/|archive-date=November 23, 2013|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|author=David Lieberman|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|url=https://www.deadline.com/2013/11/sony-pictures-to-shift-emphasis-from-movies-to-tv/|title=Sony Pictures To Shift Emphasis From Movies To TV, Will Cut Film Output For 2014|access-date=November 22, 2013}}{{cite news|author=Nellie Andreeva|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|url=https://www.deadline.com/2013/11/from-pariah-to-company-mvp-the-quiet-rise-of-sonys-television-division/|title=From Pariah To Company MVP: The Quiet Rise Of Sony's Television Division|access-date=November 22, 2013}}{{cite news|author=David Lieberman|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|url=https://www.deadline.com/2013/11/sony-tv-execs-talk-up-global-opportunities/|title=Sony TV Execs Talk Up Global Opportunities|access-date=November 22, 2013}} It was also announced on the same day, that there will be more ''Spider-Man'' sequels and spin-offs,{{cite news|author=David Lieberman|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|url=https://www.deadline.com/2013/11/sony-pictures-plans-spider-man-sequels-and-spinoffs/|title=Sony Pictures Plans More Spider-Man Sequels And Spinoffs – But Still No Marvel Reunion|access-date=November 22, 2013}} though on February 10, 2015, Sony Pictures eventually signed a deal with [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures|Disney]]'s [[Marvel Studios]] to allow Spider-Man to appear in the [[Marvel Cinematic Universe]], beginning with ''[[Captain America: Civil War]]'', before appearing in ''[[Spider-Man: Homecoming]]'' which was released on July 7, 2017.{{Cite press release|url=https://news.marvel.com/movies/24062/sony_pictures_entertainment_brings_marvel_studios_into_the_amazing_world_of_spider-man/|title=Sony Pictures Entertainment Brings Marvel Studios Into The Amazing World Of Spider-Man|publisher= Marvel|language=en-US|access-date=2017-02-11}} The deal also allowed Sony to distribute and have creative control on any MCU film where Spider-Man is the main character (such as ''Homecoming'' and its sequel ''[[Spider-Man: Far From Home]]''), while Disney will distribute MCU films where Spider-Man appears without being the main character. On January 22, 2014, SPE folded its technology unit into the various cores of its businesses.{{cite news|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|url=https://www.deadline.com/2014/01/layoffs-hit-sony-pictures-as-spe-absorbs-tech-unit/|title=Layoffs Hit Sony Pictures As SPE Absorbs Technology Unit|access-date= January 24, 2014}} In April, Sony Pictures arranged a film financing deal worth $200 million with [[LStar Capital]], the credit venture of Lone Star Capital and [[Citibank]], half in debt and the other in equity to fund most of SPE's film slate for several years. SPE was originally considering a $300 million deal with Blue Anchor Entertainment, led by Bloom Hergott partner John LaViolette and former investment banker & producer Joseph M. Singer, and backed by Longhorn Capital Management and Deutsche Bank, which was held up by regulatory matters.{{cite news|last1=Fleming|first1=Mike, Jr|title=Sony Closes Slate Co-Fi Deal With Lone Star Capital, CitiBank|url=https://deadline.com/2014/04/sony-closes-slate-co-fi-deal-with-lone-star-citibank-711875/|access-date=October 31, 2014|work=Deadline Hollywood|date=April 8, 2014}} In November 2019, Sony purchased the remaining 42% stake in GSN from [[AT&T]], placing it under the direction of its television division.{{Cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2019/11/sony-acquires-atts-42-game-show-network-stake-in-deal-worth-500m-1202789119/|title=Sony Acquires AT&T's 42% Game Show Network Stake In Deal Worth $500M|last1=Hayes|first1=Dade|date=November 18, 2019|website=Deadline|language=en|access-date=November 18, 2019}} In April 2021, Sony signed a first-look deal with [[Netflix]], allowing the streaming service to host their films following their theatrical runs and home media releases.{{Cite web|last1=Hayes|first1=Dade|date=2021-04-08|title=Netflix And Sony Break Ground With Film Licensing Deal Replacing Starz Pact, Including First Look At New Direct-To-Streaming Titles|url=https://deadline.com/2021/04/netflix-sony-pictures-licensing-deal-streaming-starz-spider-man-1234730124/|access-date=2021-04-09|website=Deadline|language=en-US}} That same month, the company also entered into a multi-year licensing agreement with [[The Walt Disney Company]] for its films to stream across Disney's streaming and linear platforms, including [[Disney+]] and [[Hulu]].{{Cite web|last=Littleton|first=Cynthia|date=2021-04-21|title=Disney Sets Massive Movie Deal With Sony Pictures, Bringing More Marvel to Disney Plus|url=https://variety.com/2021/tv/news/disney-sony-marvel-spiderman-movie-deal-1234957207/|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]}} In February 2022, Sony signed a deal with [[WarnerMedia|WarnerMedia Europe]] to stream its theatrical films on [[HBO Max]] for Central and Eastern Europe countries.{{Cite web|last1=Ramachandran|first1=Naman|date=2022-02-10|title=Sony, WarnerMedia Set Blockbuster Film Deal for HBO Max Central Europe|url=https://variety.com/2022/tv/global/sony-hbo-max-central-europe-film-deal-spider-man-ghostbusters-1235176770/|access-date=2022-03-09|website=Variety|language=en-US}} On November 28, 2022, it was announced that [[Legendary Entertainment]] reached a distribution deal with Sony to distribute its future slate of films. However, this deal does not include the [[Dune (franchise)| Dune]] and [[MonsterVerse]] films as they will remain at [[Warner Bros.]]. The deal came after the negative impact of the merger of Warner Bros.' parent company [[WarnerMedia]] with [[Discovery, Inc.]] to form [[Warner Bros. Discovery]].{{cite web | url=https://deadline.com/2022/11/sony-legendary-distribution-deal-warner-bros-dune-1235182790/ | title=Legendary & Sony Ink Multi-Year Global Theatrical Distribution Pact | date=28 November 2022 }} On December 8, 2022, Sony signed a deal with [[Crave (streaming service)|Crave]] as part of a Pay-One window licensing agreement, the two companies have entered a long-term deal, kickstarting April 2023.{{Cite web |last=Goldbart |first=Max |date=2022-12-08 |title=Sony Pictures Entertainment Inks Deal With Canada's Crave For Blockbuster Movies Including 'Spider-Man', 'Madame Web', 'Jumanji' |url=https://deadline.com/2022/12/sony-pictures-entertainment-crave-spider-man-madame-web-jumanji-1235193222/ |access-date=2023-02-17 |website=Deadline |language=en-US}} == 2014 hack == {{main|Sony Pictures hack}} In November 2014, the Sony Pictures computer network was compromised by a group of hackers named [[Guardians of Peace]], disabling many computers.{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-fi-sony-hack-20141125-story.html|title = Hack at Sony Pictures shuts computer system|work = Los Angeles Times|date = November 25, 2014}} Later the same week, five of Sony Pictures' movies were leaked, including some not yet released (such as ''[[Fury (2014 film)|Fury]]'' and ''[[Annie (2014 film)|Annie]]''), as well as confidential data about 47,000 current and former Sony employees.{{cite web |url=https://torrentfreak.com/sony-movies-leak-online-after-hack-attack-141129/ | title=Sony movies leak online after hack attack | publisher=Torrentfreak | access-date=November 30, 2014}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/03/business/media/sony-is-again-target-of-hackers.html|title = Hackers Pirate Sony Films and Leak Studio Salaries|newspaper = New York Times|date = December 2, 2014|last1 = Barnes|first1 = Brooks|last2 = Perlroth|first2 = Nicole}}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2014/12/19/lawsuits-against-sony-pictures-could-test-employer-responsibility-for-data-breaches/|title=Lawsuits against Sony Pictures could test employer responsibility for data breaches|newspaper=Washington Post}} Film historian [[Wheeler Winston Dixon]] suggested that the hack, which exposed the inner workings of the studio, was "not a pretty picture," and served as a "wake-up call to the entire industry."{{cite news|author=MEG JAMES, RYAN FAUGHNDER|date=December 13, 2014|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-fi-ct-sony-emails-20141213-story.html#page=1|title=Fallout from Sony hack may alter how Hollywood conducts business|access-date=December 14, 2014}} The hack also revealed some other documents, emails between Hollywood moguls referring to [[Barack Obama]]'s cinematic tastes, a possible partnership with [[Marvel Studios]] for the inclusion of the superhero [[Spider-Man]] in ''[[Captain America: Civil War]]'', which was later confirmed in February 2015, amongst others.{{Cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/sony-hack-amy-pascal-scott-756438|title=Sony Hack: Amy Pascal and Scott Rudin Joked About Obama's Race in Leaked Emails|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=2014-12-10|access-date=2017-10-15|language=en}}[https://mashable.com/2014/12/12/spider-man-may-appear-in-captain-america-3-but-not-played-by-andrew-garfield/ Spider-Man may appear in 'Captain America 3'] mashable.com On December 16, the hackers issued a warning to moviegoers, threatening to attack anyone who sees ''[[The Interview]]'' during the holidays and urging people to "remember [[September 11 attacks|the 11th of September 2001]]".{{cite news | title= Sony Hackers Threaten Movie Theaters |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2014/12/16/sony-hackers-threaten-movie-theaters/20485591/| publisher= USA Today | date= December 16, 2014}} On December 17, 2014, Sony cancelled the previously planned December 25 release of ''[[The Interview]]'' in response to hacker threats.{{cite news | title= Sony pulls 'The Interview'; the Internet reacts |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/102278994| publisher= CNBC | date= December 18, 2014}} On February 24, 2015, [[Tom Rothman]] was named chairman of SPE's motion picture group to replace Amy Pascal.{{cite news|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|url=https://deadline.com/2015/02/tom-rothman-replaces-amy-pascal-1201380416/|title=Tom Rothman Replaces Amy Pascal At Sony Pictures; Michael Lynton Contract News]]|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-02-24/sony-names-former-fox-film-chief-tom-rothman-to-replace-pascal|title=Sony Names Former Fox Film Chief Tom Rothman to Replace Pascal|access-date=February 24, 2015}} On April 16, 2015, [[WikiLeaks]] published over 30,287 documents, 173 e-mails, and 2,200 corporate e-mail addresses of Sony Pictures' employees. WikiLeaks said in a press release that the content of the leaks were "newsworthy and at the center of a geo-political conflict" and belonged "in the public domain". Sony Pictures later condemned the hack and subsequent leaks, calling it a "malicious criminal act", while also criticizing WikiLeaks for describing the leaked content as [[public domain]].{{cite web|work=Los Angeles Times|url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-wikileaks-sony-hack-20150416-story.html|title=Sony Pictures condemns WikiLeaks' release of hacked material|date=16 April 2015|author=Saba Hamedy|access-date=30 November 2017}}{{cite web|author=Eriq Gardner|publisher=Yahoo! Based on the timeline of events and the amount of information hacked, he believes the hack may have been conducted by a Sony employee.{{Cite web |url=https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2018/04/seth-rogen-north-korea-sony-hack |title=Actually, Seth Rogen Doesn't Think North Korea Was Behind the Sony Hack |last=Desta |first=Yohana |website=HWD |date=April 30, 2018 |language=en |access-date=2018-07-28}} == Corporate structure == Headquartered in [[Culver City, California]], U.S., SPE comprises various studios and entertainment brands, including [[Columbia Pictures]], [[Screen Gems]], [[TriStar Pictures]] and [[Game Show Network|GSN]]. === Senior management team === * [[Anthony Vinciquerra]] ** Chairman and CEO, Sony Pictures Entertainment * [[Tom Rothman]] ** Chairman, Sony Pictures Motion Picture Group{{cite web|title=Sony Pictures - Divisions|url=https://www.sonypictures.com/corp/divisions.html|website=sonypictures.com|access-date=June 7, 2015}} === Motion Pictures and Home Entertainment === * [[Sony Pictures Motion Picture Group]]: formerly Columbia TriStar Motion Picture Group. With a library of more than 4,000 films (including 12 [[Academy Award for Best Picture]] winners), as of 2004 this unit of Sony distributes about 22 films a year under its various studio brands in 67 countries.{{cite web|url=https://www.sonypictures.com/corp/corporatefact.html|title=Sony Pictures – Corporate Factsheet|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051104051441/http://www.sonypictures.com/corp/corporatefact.html|archive-date=November 4, 2005|df=mdy-all}} The group owns studio facilities in the United States, Hong Kong, [[Madrid]], Mexico, the United Kingdom, Brazil and Japan. ** [[Columbia Pictures]]: Founded in 1924 by [[Harry Cohn]], Sony acquired the studio in 1989 from [[The Coca-Cola Company]] for $3.4 billion. ** [[TriStar Pictures]]: Formed in 1982 as a joint venture between Columbia Pictures, [[HBO]], and [[CBS]]. Became part of Columbia Pictures Entertainment in December 1987 and the Sony ownership in 1989. Was relaunched in 2004 as a marketing and acquisitions unit that specializes in the genre and independent films. *** [[TriStar Productions]]: A joint-venture between [[Thomas Rothman]] and SPE. ** [[Screen Gems]]: Originally Columbia's animation division and later a television production company best known for TV's ''[[Bewitched]]'' and ''[[The Partridge Family]]'', as well as bringing [[The Three Stooges]] [[short subject]]s to TV in 1958. Sony revived the Screen Gems brand in 1998 to develop mid-priced movies (production budget of between $20 million and $50 million) in specific genres such as science fiction, [[horror film|horror]], black cinema and franchise films. ** [[Sony Pictures Imageworks]],{{cite web|title=Sony Pictures Imageworks|url=https://www.imageworks.com/about.php|website=imageworks.com}} visual effect ** [[Sony Pictures Animation]], producing Animation films ** [[Sony Pictures Classics]]: Founded in 1992, Sony's [[Art film|specialty film]] label that distributes, produces and acquires films such as [[Documentary film|documentaries]], [[Independent film|independent]] and [[Art film|arthouse]] films in the United States and internationally. ** 3000 Pictures: A production company that was launched on July 2019 by Elizabeth Gabler, former [[Fox 2000 Pictures]] president, who henced the name. This is a joint venture between Sony Pictures Entertainment and [[HarperCollins]], producing HarperCollins adaptations ** [[Sony Pictures Motion Picture Group#Sony Pictures Releasing|Sony Pictures Releasing]]: Founded in 1994[https://businessprofiles.com/details/sony-pictures-releasing/NY-1358802 SONY PICTURES RELEASING CORPORATION] businessprofiles.com, Retrieved on January 20, 2014 as a successor to Triumph Releasing Corporation. The unit handles distribution, marketing, and promotion for films produced by Sony Pictures Entertainment; including Columbia Pictures, TriStar Pictures, Screen Gems, Sony Pictures Classics, among others.{{ref|1|1}} *** Sony Pictures Releasing International (formerly Columbia TriStar Film Distributors International) **** Sony Pictures India: A production house established by Sony to release Indian movies and distribute Hollywood movies released under Columbia Pictures. **** Sony Pictures International Productions: A division that produces films in local languages other than English around the world. ** [[Sony Pictures Home Entertainment]]: Founded in 1978 as Columbia Pictures Home Entertainment. Currently manufactures and distributes the Sony film and television libraries on [[Blu-ray]], [[Ultra HD Blu-ray]], [[3D Blu-ray]], [[DVD]], and [[digital distribution|digital download]] *** [[Sony Wonder]]: The former kids and family label of [[Sony Music Entertainment]] that was moved to SPHE on June 21, 2007. *** [[Genius Brands]] (minority stake) ****[[Wow Unlimited Media]] *****[[Mainframe Studios]] *****[[Frederator Networks]] *****Ezrin Hirsh Entertainment ** [[Sony Pictures Worldwide Acquisitions]] (SPWA): A Sony division which acquires and produces about 60 films per year for a wide variety of distribution platforms, especially for non-theatrical markets. It had been called "Worldwide SPE Acquisitions, Inc." until September 2010. *** [[Destination Films]]: A motion picture company which currently specializes in action, thriller, sci-fi, niche and low-end to medium-end horror films was purchased by Sony in 2001. *** [[Stage 6 Films]]: A [[direct-to-video]] label created in 2007. Also releases some films theatrically. *** [[Affirm Films]]: A motion picture label launched in 2008 to release gospel and Christian films. **** Pure Flix: A streaming service, owned by Affirm Films. === Television === ==== U.S. production and distribution ==== * [[Sony Pictures Television]]: (formerly Columbia TriStar Television Group) The successor-in-interest to Columbia's television division (first Screen Gems, later [[Columbia Pictures Television]], [[TriStar Television]], and [[Columbia TriStar Television]]), as of 2004 the unit was producing 60 titles for various television outlets globally. Contains a library that includes more than 35,000 episodes of more than 270 television series and 22,000 game show episodes under the Sony Pictures Television brand, and the television rights to the [[Embassy Pictures]] library (including ''[[The Graduate]]'' and ''[[The Lion in Winter (1968 film)|The Lion in Winter]]'') and also the owner of the television division "[[Embassy Television]]"—among most recent notable shows in this library are ''[[Party of Five]]'', ''[[The Shield]]'', ''[[Seinfeld]]'', ''[[The King of Queens]]'', ''[[Days of Our Lives]]'' and ''[[The Young and the Restless]]''. Their former international distribution division, Sony Pictures Television International, was responsible for global distribution for the SPE film and television properties worldwide.
